awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Patient-Led Research Practices in Complex Chronic Illness Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Open sources have become an important resource of health information, particularly for people living with illnesses that may not be well understood. For these patients, for whom diagnosis and treatment processes may take a great deal of time and involve protracted experiences of medical uncertainty, new forms of digital media can be a crucial resource for accessing information and peer support. In some cases, informal patient research has succeeded in generating clinically important insights about emerging and uncertain illnesses. In addition to providing training for a graduate student in scientific methods of data collection and analysis, the findings and data would be disseminated to improve the public's understanding of science and the scientific method, with important implications for improving clinical practice and patient care.

This doctoral dissertation project uses ethnographic methods to examine how people living with medically underdetermined chronic illnesses use online tools and forums to connect with peers, develop strategies for manage their symptoms, and conduct informal research about their conditions. This research investigates three main questions. How do online communities help patients navigate ambiguity and uncertainty with respect to their health? How do they collaboratively find and produce information about their conditions? In what ways do these practices impact the trajectories of their illnesses? This project use observational research in online groups for complex chronic illness patients, interviews with group participants, and narrative analysis of media produced by complex chronic illness patients. Analysis illuminate the ways in which participants use digital technologies to collaboratively develop new conceptual frameworks for understanding medically uncertain illnesses. This research anticipates producing data of interest to clinicians and public health practitioners about patient experiences of medical uncertainty. It will also have implications for social scientists with respect to the role of the internet in emerging cultural practices of knowledge production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This study examined how people living with complex, medically under-determined chronic illnesses make sense of their experiences through self-experimentation and the use of online forums and self-help groups. Much remains uncertain about the nature and origins of many complex chronic illnesses, and there is little consensus in the medical community about best practices for treating them. Thus, patients often turn to the internet for information, advice, and peer support. In the context of widespread social concern about the impacts of online medical misinformation and the authority of conventional scientific expertise, “doing one’s own research” is both broadly politicized and occasionally stigmatized. At the same time, patient-led research and advocacy that foregrounds lived experience of illness have made critical contributions to emerging knowledge about complex chronic diseases. Findings suggest that while most participants strongly desired conventional biomedical expert care, it was often difficult to access. It is only in the context of that difficulty that participants pursued alternatives. As they did so, the fragmentary and decentralized structure of the U.S. healthcare system in addition to the enormous array of health and wellness industry products and services intensified the interpretive challenges associated with complex chronic illnesses: information was extremely abundant, but deciphering which information was (1) reliable and scientifically sound, and (2) relevant to a particular individual’s situation proved difficult. In this context, participants came to place high value on experiential knowledge (both their own and that of their peers), and rely on it to filter, mediate, and make sense of knowledge from other sources.

Every participant in this project sought treatment from conventional biomedical doctors before resorting to either non-biomedical healing modalities or self-experimentation. However, participant accounts suggest that many medical doctors have little education or experience treating complex chronic diseases, and that attempts to do so are often stymied by barriers imposed by hospitals, practices, and insurance companies (such as long wait times for appointments, limits on appointment duration, lack of communication between providers, and non-approval of exploratory testing or experimental interventions). While clinicians working in private practice and outside the commercial insurance system offered more flexibility, their services were financially out of reach for many.

Beyond conventional clinics and hospitals, the booming health and wellness industries offered a huge array of adjunctive and quasi-therapuetic products and services. For those who made use of them, however, these services do not necessarily produce a greater degree certainty about the nature of the health condition in question, nor actionable insight. Rather, participants often struggled to make sense of abundant variety of ambiguously meaningful data from multiple sources in addition to multiple, sometimes conflicting interpretations from medical specialists and healers of other kinds. While some services and providers were considered more reliable than others, overall, the fragmentary and decentralized structure of the U.S. healthcare system produced uncertainty about the trustworthiness and scientific soundness of the entire enterprise.

Practices of self-experimentation and illness self-management outside of conventional biomedicine were also strongly influenced by practical exigency and contingency. Participants’ beliefs about which treatment options were most likely to be effective or best supported by scientific evidence often came second to considerations such as cost, geographical proximity, and time. Persistence in experimentation even with healing modalities about which participants were strongly skeptical was frequent; most participants were highly motivated to find a way to improve their symptoms, even while exhausted and demoralized by the project. This persistence was driven by both ideological and material forces. U.S. American cultural values of self-reliance and productivity made participants reluctant to “give up” or accept limitations imposed by chronic symptoms. At the same time, significant economic precarity (insofar as illness limited participants’ ability to work) made the search for effective treatment and matter of urgency.

In general, participants in online forums were aware of medical misinformation as a general social problem and made an effort to exercise discernment in their self-directed research ventures. However, information listed on, for example, the websites of major academic medical centers or the CDC was often too general to be helpful, while academic-scientific literature was difficult and time consuming to read for those without specialized education, and often lacked clear clinical or experimental application. In this context, study participants relied upon their own and their peers’ experiential knowledge to make sense of abundant but nonspecific information. Online forums were an invaluable knowledge resource insofar as they function as (1) extensive archives of accumulated experiential knowledge and, (2) as informal workshops where participants refine self-experimental procedures and interpret results through peer feedback and discussion. Where participants’ beliefs about complex chronic illness (both their own particular illnesses and diagnostic categories more broadly) deviated from biomedical interpretations, it was generally as a result of trying to make sense of or reconcile dissonance between personal experiences and received academic or scientific knowledge.
